00038 # ^function step
00039 sub step {     # heavyside function (1 or x>0)
00040     my $x = shift;
00041     ($x > 0 ) ? 1 : 0;
00042 }
00043 # ^function ceil
00044 sub ceil {
00045     my $x = shift;
00046     - floor(-$x);
00047 }
00048 # ^function floor
00049 sub floor {
00050     my $input = shift;
00051     my $out = int $input;
00052     $out -- if ( $out <= 0 and ($out-$input) > 0 );  # does the right thing for negative numbers
00053     $out;
00054 }

00056 # ^function max
00057 sub max {
00058 
00059         my $maxVal = shift;
00060         my @input = @_;
00061 
00062         foreach my $num (@input) {
00063                 $maxVal = $num if ($maxVal < $num);
00064         }
00065 
00066         $maxVal;
00067 
00068 }
00069 
00070 # ^function min
00071 sub min {
00072 
00073         my $minVal = shift;
00074         my @input = @_;
00075 
00076         foreach my $num (@input) {
00077                 $minVal = $num if ($minVal > $num);
00078         }
00079 
00080         $minVal;
00081 
00082 }

00100 # Round contributed bt Mark Schmitt 3-6-03
00101 # ^function Round
00102 # ^uses Round
00103 sub Round {
00104     if (@_ == 1) { $_[0] > 0 ? int $_[0] + 0.5 : int $_[0] - 0.5}
00105     elsif (@_ == 2) { $_[0] > 0 ? Round($_[0]*10**$_[1])/10**$_[1] :Round($_[0]*10**$_[1])/10**$_[1]}
00106 }

00108 #least common multiple
00109 #VS 6/29/2000
00110 # ^function lcm
00111 sub lcm {
00112     my $a = shift;
00113     my $b = shift;
00114 
00115     #reorder such that $a is the smaller number
00116     if ($a > $b) {
00117         my $temp = $a;
00118         $a = $b;
00119         $b = $temp;
00120     }
00121 
00122     my $lcm = 0;
00123     my $curr = $b;;
00124 
00125     while($lcm == 0) {
00126         $lcm = $curr if ($curr % $a == 0);
00127         $curr += $b;
00128     }
00129 
00130     $lcm;
00131 
00132 }

00135 # greatest common factor
00136 # takes in two scalar values and uses the Euclidean Algorithm to return the gcf
00137 #VS 6/29/2000
00138 # ^function gcf
00139 sub gcf {
00140         my $a = abs(shift); # absolute values because this will yield the same gcd,
00141         my $b = abs(shift); # but allows use of the mod operation
00142 
00143     # reorder such that b is the smaller number
00144     if ($a < $b) {
00145         my $temp = $a;
00146         $a = $b;
00147         $b = $temp;
00148     }
00149 
00150     return $a if $b == 0;
00151 
00152     my $q = int($a/$b); # quotient
00153     my $r = $a % $b;    # remainder
00154 
00155     return $b if $r == 0;
00156 
00157     my $tempR = $r;
00158 
00159     while ($r != 0) {
00160 
00161         #keep track of what $r was in the last loop, as this is the value
00162         #we will want when $r is set to 0
00163         $tempR = $r;
00164 
00165         $a = $b;
00166         $b = $r;
00167         $q = $a/$b;
00168         $r = $a % $b;
00169 
00170     }
00171 
00172     $tempR;
00173 }
00174

00176 #greatest common factor.
00177 #same as gcf, but both names are sufficiently common names
00178 # ^function gcd
00179 # ^uses gcf
00180 sub gcd {
00181         return gcf($_[0], $_[1]);
00182 }

00184 #returns 1 for a prime number, else 0
00185 #VS 6/30/2000
00186 # ^function isPrime
00187 sub isPrime {
00188         my $num = shift;
00189         return 1 if ($num == 2 or $num == 3);
00190         return 0 if ($num == 1 or $num == 0);
00191         for (my $i = 2; $i <= sqrt($num); $i++) { return 0 if ($num % $i == 0); }
00192         return 1;
00193 }
00194 
00195 #reduces a fraction, returning an array containing ($numerator, $denominator)
00196 #VS 7/10/2000
00197 # ^function reduce
00198 # ^uses gcd
00199 sub reduce {
00200 
00201     my $num = shift;
00202     my $denom = shift;
00203     my $gcd = gcd($num, $denom);
00204 
00205     $num = $num/$gcd;
00206     $denom = $denom/$gcd;
00207 
00208     # formats such that only the numerator will be negative
00209     if ($num/$denom < 0) {$num = -abs($num); $denom = abs($denom);}
00210     else {$num = abs($num); $denom = abs($denom);}
00211 
00212     my @frac = ($num, $denom);
00213     @frac;
00214 }

00217 # takes a number and fixed object, as in "$a x" and formats
00218 # to account for when $a = 0, 1, -1
00219 # Usage: preformat($scalar, "quoted string");
00220 # Example: preformat(-1, "\pi") returns "-\pi"
00221 # VS 8/1/2000  -  slight adaption of code from T. Shemanske of Dartmouth College
00222 # ^function preformat
00223 sub preformat {
00224     my $num = shift;
00225     my $obj = shift;
00226     my $out;
00227 
00228 
00229     if ($num == 0) { return 0; }
00230     elsif ($num == 1) { return $obj; }
00231     elsif ($num == -1) { return "-".$obj; }
00232 
00233     return $num.$obj;
00234 }

00236 #factorial
00237 # ^function fact
00238 # ^uses P
00239 sub fact {
00240     P($_[0], $_[0]);
00241 }
